title: 114_s348
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Lands Against Narcotics Trafficking Act of 2015" or the "PLANT Act." Amendments are made to the Controlled Substances Act penalties. Amendments are made to the Controlled Substances Act regarding penalties for cultivating or manufacturing controlled substances on federal property. The United States Sentencing Commission is tasked with amending the Federal Sentencing Guidelines to enhance penalties for violations that pose environmental hazards. The Controlled Substances Act prohibits stream diversion, clear cutting, and destruction of bodies of water or timber on federal property or while trespassing. Penalties are enhanced for violations that create hazards to humans, wildlife, or the environment. The Controlled Substances Act imposes fines up to $500,000 for individuals and $1,000,000 for entities who obstruct or damage water sources or timber while cultivating controlled substances on federal property or trespassing. The Controlled Substances Act imposes fines for violations, with amounts transferred to the Secretary of the Interior to address environmental damage. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and enhance federal sentencing guidelines. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend Federal Sentencing Guidelines to enhance penalties for violations of the Controlled Substances Act involving environmental damage. The Controlled Substances Act is being amended to include penalties for booby traps on federal property and the use of firearms in connection with drug offenses. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend Federal Sentencing Guidelines to enhance penalties for these violations. Enhancement of 1 offense level for violating section 401(a) of the Controlled Substances Act if possessing a firearm while cultivating or manufacturing drugs on Federal property or while trespassing on another's property.
